headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Allegion Q3 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded.I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Tom Martineau, Director of
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Allegion Q3 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded.
I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Tom Martineau, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, please begin.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Liz. Good morning, everyone. Welcome, and thank you for joining us for the Third Quarter 2015 Allegion Earnings Call. With me today is Dave Petratis, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Patrick Shannon, Senior Vice President an
componenttext:
Thank you, Liz. Good morning, everyone. Welcome, and thank you for joining us for the Third Quarter 2015 Allegion Earnings Call. With me today is Dave Petratis, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Patrick Shannon, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Allegion. 
Our earnings release, which was issued earlier this morning, and the presentation, which we will refer to in today's call, are available on our website at www.allegion.com. This call will be recorded and archived on our website. 
Please go to Slide #2. Statements made in today's call that are not historical facts are considered forward-looking statements and are made pursuant to the Safe Harbor Provisions of federal securities law. Please see our SEC filings for description of some of the factors that may cause actual results to vary from anticipated results. The company assumes no obligation to update these forward-looking statements. 
Our release and today's commentary includes non-GAAP financial measures, which exclude the impact of restructuring, acquisition and divestiture, expenses and charges in currency results and restructuring and spin expenses from prior year results. We believe these adjustments reflect the underlying performance the business when discussing operational results in comparing to the prior year periods. Please refer to the reconciliation on the financial tables of our press release for further details. 
Dave and Patrick will discuss our third quarter 2015 results, which will be followed by a Q&A session. [Operator Instructions] 
Please go to Slide 3, and I'll turn the call over to Dave.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Good morning and thank you for joining us today. I'm pleased to report another strong quarter for Allegion with nice organic growth and operating margin expansion. There has been a tremendous amount of positive activity during this past quart
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Good morning and thank you for joining us today. I'm pleased to report another strong quarter for Allegion with nice organic growth and operating margin expansion. There has been a tremendous amount of positive activity during this past quarter and we'll be covering in today's call. 
Revenues of $544 million grew 5.1% on an organic basis. Total revenue declined four tenths of a percent, reflecting the negative impact of foreign currency. Of note, organic growth for the businesses has averaged more than 6% over the last 12 months. And our electronics portfolio continues to perform well in the quarter improving more than 30% versus prior year. We have seen a continuous acceleration of the electronic growth rate, reflective of the ongoing electromechanical transformation and supportive of our increased investment in accelerating new electronic security products and solutions. 
The Americas segment grew 7% organically, driven by continued strength in both the nonresidential and residential business. In EMEIA, organic growth of 2% reflects a slight improvement in the region, although market recovery continues to be mixed across countries. Our one decline this quarter is in the Asia Pacific region with negative organic growth of 10%. Patrick will provide more details on this later, but the decline is primarily driven by weakness in our system integration business in China. 
Adjusted operating income of $160.8 million increased 5.3% versus the prior year. We realized operating margin expansion in all regions and improved overall margin by 120 basis points. We continue to show margin improvement while absorbing incremental investments, investments predominantly in new products and channel initiatives created a 90 basis point headwind in the quarter. Adjusted earnings per share of $0.92 increased 35% versus the prior year, driven primarily from improved operating performance, acquisition and a lower effective tax rate, partially offset by incremental investments and foreign exchange impacts. This is our fifth straight quarter with double-digit earnings per share growth. We are raising our full year 2015 adjusted earnings per share guidance of a -- to a range of $2.85 to $2.90 per share. 
Please go to Slide 4. We have been extremely active as a company affecting change in line with our long-term growth strategies. I'm happy to report that we successfully closed the 3 acquisitions mentioned last quarter within the expected time frame. We are well underway with the integration work and have already seen contribution in our third quarter results. We are excited to realize the benefits of a broader electronics portfolio as well as seeing the expansion of our position as a global leader in portable security. 
During the quarter, we completed the divestiture of our Venezuela business. This decision was made to reduce risks associated with an uncertain economic operating environment. Also in the quarter, we announced our intent to sell a majority stake in our Bocom Wincent business in China. Although a market leader in the system integration industry in China, this business was not deemed to be a good strategic fit with the rest of the Allegion portfolio. The sale has the benefit of reducing risk to the environment that is currently realizing its economic flowing combined with tightened credit and reduces the high cap capital requirements of the business. This decision allows us to prioritize efforts and resources on core mechanical and electronic hardware solutions. And earlier this month, we reached an agreement with regard to the restructuring plans for our CISA business in Italy that will ensure long-term viability enhance the customer experience. CISA remains a critical part of the European portfolio and will continue to provide innovative solutions for convergence of mechanical and electronic technologies. In conjunction with the plan, we will begin to transition products of nonspecialized products to Flex, an existing supplier of Allegion today. Flex offers innovative design, engineering, manufacturing, real-time supply chain insight and logistical services to companies of all sizes in various industries around today's connected world. By partnering with Flex, we will simplify and optimize our supply chain, reducing risks associated with the transition and will better serve our customer needs. And last, we enhanced our debt structure with the issuance of 300 million of senior notes as well as completing an amendment and extension of our senior credit facility. The proceeds of the senior notes were used to repay a portion of our outstanding borrowings under the revolving credit facility as a result of the previous completed acquisitions. 
Please go to Slide 5. On September 1, we launched pre-orders for Schlage newest Internet of Things innovation, the Schlage Sense Mark Deadbolt at amazon.com, homedepot.com and build.com. Schlage Sense is one of the strongest, most intelligent Bluetooth enabled locks on the market with the highest industry rating for security and durability. It's designed to work with Apple HomeKit, allowing users to control their doorlock as part of their smartphone. Apple HomeKit technology provides advanced security with end-to-end encryption and authentication between the Schlage Sense Mark Deadbolt and an iPhone, an iPad or an iPod Touch. With an Apple TV at home, users can enjoy the convenience of remote access. Additionally, HomeKit let's consumers talk to their -- to unlock their Schlage Sense using Siri voice control. In November, Schlage Sense will be available in Apple Stores and online. This lock has received media attention from large industry [indiscernible] like CNET and Hardware Building Supply Viewer, along with praise with tech industry publications like Mashable, Tech Crunch and Mac Rumors. I'm also proud to say it's been featured by large national media outlets like Fortune and CNBC. Schlage Sense will be officially be available in retail in November in selected Big Box stores like Home Depot and Lowe's. 
Patrick will now walk you through the financial results, and I'll be back up to update you on our full year 2015 guidance.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining the call this morning. Please go to Slide #6. This slide depicts the components of our revenue growth in the third quarter as well as our growth by regional segment. As indicated, we delive
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining the call this morning. 
Please go to Slide #6. This slide depicts the components of our revenue growth in the third quarter as well as our growth by regional segment. As indicated, we delivered 5.1% organic growth in the third quarter supported by incremental volume that reflects improving market fundamentals, price improvements and early traction on our key organic growth investments and products and channels. We realized solid organic growth in the Americas and EMEIA segments. As expected, unfavorable foreign currency rates continue to be a headwind to revenue growth noted by the negative 7.5% decline. All reporting segments were impacted by currency due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar against currencies in EMEIA and Asia Pacific as well as the devaluation of Venezuelan Bolivar. Acquisition and divestitures provided 2% of growth, which includes contributions from acquisitions offset by Venezuelan divestiture. 
Please go to Slide #7. Reported net revenues for the quarter were $544.5 million. This reflects a decrease of 0.4% versus the prior year, up 5.1% on an organic basis. We realized strong organic growth in Americas and EMEIA across most product segments. We continue to experience great progress in electronic product growth, up over 30% compared to the prior-year period. This growth was across both residential and commercial segments and is the result of new products and accelerated adoption of electronic products. 
Adjusted operating income of $116.8 million grew 5.3% compared to the prior year. Incremental volume leverage and acquisitions compensated for increased investment spending and unfavorable foreign currency exchange rate movements. Adjusted operating margin of 21.5% reflects an increase of 120 basis points versus the prior year. Incremental investments made in the areas of new product development, channel and market expansion and certain infrastructure programs have a negative impact of 90 basis points on the quarter. The adjusted EBITDA margin of 23.7% is a record performance since the company went public in December 2013. 
Please go to Slide #8. This slide reflects our EPS reconciliation for the third quarter. For the third quarter of 2014, reported EPS was $0.65, adjusting for prior year onetime separation and restructuring expenses of $0.03, the 2014 adjusted EPS was $0.68. Operational results increased EPS by $0.12 as pricing, productivity and favorable operating leverage were more than offset inflation and unfavorable currency exchange impacts. The decrease in the adjusted effective tax rate drove $0.15 per share improvement versus the prior year. The improvement reflects favorable changes in the mix of income earned and lower rate jurisdictions and the benefit of discrete tax items recorded in the quarter. Acquisitions and interest expense added $0.02, as did other net items. Next, incremental investments related to ongoing growth opportunities for new product development and channel management as well as corporate initiatives tied to our strategy specific to taxes and IT investments were a $0.03 reduction. And lastly, the net year-over-year impact of Venezuela at current exchange rates is a $0.04 reduction. These result in adjusted third quarter 2015 EPS of $0.92 per share. 
Continuing on, we have a negative $1.20 per share reduction for charges related to the Bocom Wincent and Venezuelan business divestitures as well as acquisition and restructuring expenses. After giving effect to these onetime items, we arrived at the third quarter 2015 reported EPS of negative $0.28. 
Please go to Slide #9. Third quarter revenues for the Americas region were $418.9 million, down 1% or an increase of 7% on an organic basis. Higher volumes, pricing and contribution from the acquisition of Zero compensated for unfavorable currency movements in Canada, in Venezuela and the divestiture of the Venezuelan business. The higher volumes reflect strong organic growth in both residential and nonresidential products. This reflects better-than-market performance driven by our new product and channel initiatives. Americas adjusted operating income of $122.2 million was down 1% versus the prior-year period. Pricing and productivity more than offset inflation and investment, while incremental volume was absorbed by unfavorable foreign exchange rates in the Venezuelan divestiture. Adjusted operating margin for the quarter increased 10 basis points while absorbing incremental investment spending that created a 70 basis point headwind in the quarter and unfavorable mix due to the Venezuelan divestiture. 
Please go to Slide #10. Third quarter revenues for the EMEIA region were $91.5 million, up 2.2% growth both on a reported and an organic basis. The growth was driven by strong pricing within the mechanical business and modest volume increases. Significant ongoing currency headwinds were offset by recent acquisitions completed in the quarter. EMEIA adjusted operating income of $5.9 million was up $4.7 million or 392% versus the prior-year period. Adjusted operating margin for the quarter increased 510 basis points, reflected continued improvements in an ongoing business transformation as well as partial quarter contributions from the recent acquisitions, which were accretive to the region's margins. 
Please go to Slide #11. Third quarter revenues for the Asia Pacific region were $34.1 million, flat to the prior year. Revenues were down 10.2% on an organic basis. Strength in the hardware business and acquisitions offset unfavorable foreign exchange and a decline in the Bocom Wincent system integration business. The decline reflects the slowdown of the China business environment and the delay of a few large projects. Note that this business historically relies on large project awards in the second half of the year. During the third quarter, projects in the pipeline have been delayed, resulting a year-over-year reduction of revenue of approximately $6 million or negative 36%. We also expect an impact to the fourth quarter organic growth rates, which Dave will discuss later. Of note, the announced divestiture of Bocom Wincent to assist future risk inherent in the seasonal nature of the business both in terms of size and timing of awards. Asia Pacific adjusted operating income of $0.7 million was up $1.2 million or 240% versus the prior year. Adjusted operating margin improved 360 basis points due to the mixed shift of hardware volume, productivity and acquisitions, which offset inflation and currency exchange impacts. 
Please go to Slide #12. Year-to-date available cash flow for 2015 was $98.7 million, a reduction of $36.3 million compared to the prior-year period. The reduction in year-over-year cash flow was due to increased operating cash requirements and onetime cash tax payments partially offset by reduced capital expenditures. We continue to operate with an effective working capital structure and continue to see improvement in working capital as a percentage of revenue as well as our cash conversion cycle. We expect full year available cash flow for the business to be approximately $200 million. This guidance incorporates a reduction in anticipated 2015 collections for our Bocom Wincent business and slightly higher working capital requirements. 
I will now hand it back over to Dave for an update on our full year 2015 guidance.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Patrick. Please go to Slide 13. Looking at full year revenue guidance, we are increasing our growth expectations for the full year by a point. In the Americas, we're improving organic revenue growth by 50 basis points, [indiscernible] the third
componenttext:
Thank you, Patrick. Please go to Slide 13. Looking at full year revenue guidance, we are increasing our growth expectations for the full year by a point. In the Americas, we're improving organic revenue growth by 50 basis points, [indiscernible] the third quarter results. Reported full year revenue growth for the Americas remains consistent to prior guidance as the increases in organic revenue is offset by increased currency headwinds. We've seen end markets as unchanged from prior guidance with regard to verticals or construction growth. 
Total revenue for EMEIA region now reflects the inclusion of the SimonsVoss and AXA acquisitions, while organic growth guidance remains unchanged. The largest change occurs within our Asia Pacific region where we now forecast organic revenue to decline for the full year by negative 13% to 15%. This impact flows through the total Asia Pacific revenues that are primarily offset by the inclusion of the Milre acquisition. 
As Patrick mentioned earlier, when discussing Q3 results, the revenue call down [ph] is related to the Bocom Wincent system integration business where we now forecast a number of large projects to be delayed until 2016. And note that we would continue to include Bocom Wincent in our guidance as announced, but not yet closed transaction. Furthermore, margins for Bocom Wincent are historically strongest in the fourth quarter due to increased volume, which compensates for operating losses in the first 3 quarters. Given the reduction of volume, we expect full year margin for Asia Pacific to be down from prior year and close to breakeven. We estimate the earnings impact of a lower Bocom Wincent revenues in the fourth quarter to be a headwind of approximately $0.05 versus prior guidance. Inclusive of this impact, we are still able to increase full year adjusted EPS from continuing operations to the range of $2.85 to $2.90. This reflects an improvement of our adjusted effective tax rate now estimated to be 20% for the full year and improved operational performance. Furthermore, this incorporates the impact of acquisitions as well as increased interest expense related to the new senior notes. 
Please go to Slide 14. The third quarter results were very strong and represented solid growth with a 5.1% organic revenue increase, a 120 basis point margin expansion and adjusted earnings per share growth of over 35%. From a market perspective, the trends for the U.S. market are still leaning positive, although economic data remains choppy. And after a long recessionary cycle, we are seeing signs of slight improvements in our primary European geographies. In Asia Pacific, China growth is accelerating, while other countries outside China are holding. Overall, the business continues to perform well, and we are executing at a high level. We're making the top portfolio decisions that need to be made and we'll continue to execute on our strategies to drive profitable growth and customer satisfaction. 
Now Patrick and I will be happy to take your questions.

So I just wanted to get a quick update on your initial thoughts as we move forward over the next 6 to 12 months on institutional.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we see the institutional markets, they continue to lean positive, but we don't see a huge sea change in the environment that we've operated in previously. I recently was at our California field office and was extremely pleased with the bond approvals
componenttext: Yes, we see the institutional markets, they continue to lean positive, but we don't see a huge sea change in the environment that we've operated in previously. I recently was at our California field office and was extremely pleased with the bond approvals for Southern California schools. So it tends to support our view and I think your view that institutional spending, state government spending is improving, but we're still nowhere near normal.

componenttext: Okay. But net-net, would you say that that should be an incremental positive as you look at -- start to think about '16 versus this year?

componenttextpreview: I think it's a mixed bag. It's positive as I saw in California. You move into some of the oil patches like Texas, which has been a good driver, softer. So I think you've got to take into context, we continue to be leaning positive, but we still think we'v
componenttext: I think it's a mixed bag. It's positive as I saw in California. You move into some of the oil patches like Texas, which has been a good driver, softer. So I think you've got to take into context, we continue to be leaning positive, but we still think we've got a couple of years for that institutional state budgets to normalize.

componenttextpreview: So we reviewed our channel initiatives and growth in the retrofit and tenant improvement buildout in the quarter. The results are exceeding our expectations, but I want to ground you. We launched that program in 6 cities. I said clearly, our target is to
componenttext: So we reviewed our channel initiatives and growth in the retrofit and tenant improvement buildout in the quarter. The results are exceeding our expectations, but I want to ground you. We launched that program in 6 cities. I said clearly, our target is to launch that across the United States and Canada, let's say, 32 cities and we'll do over 36 months. But we're pleased with the progress and it's embedded in our organic growth and we see further progress as we move into '16 and '17. I think why wouldn't I go faster. This programs got to be done correctly and it takes people. And so pleased with the results and we'll continue to work on these areas.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: We would say yes.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Got you. And then maybe just a quick one on pricing. I mean pricing has been accelerating for the last few quarters. Just curious about what's driving that. I assume some of the new products, but also the outlook for pricing.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We raised prices end of Q3. We saw some effects of that in the quarter. I would say the pricing in the environment continues to be slightly positive. I think in the Americas, we got a little less than 1%. And we continue to see that moving forward as oppo
componenttext: We raised prices end of Q3. We saw some effects of that in the quarter. I would say the pricing in the environment continues to be slightly positive. I think in the Americas, we got a little less than 1%. And we continue to see that moving forward as opportunistic. How can we sharpen our gain in terms of achieving price realization on the commercial as well as the residential side.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Yes, and just a little bit more color too, Rob. The majority of that price increase or what you're seeing in the numbers year-over-year is on the commercial side. Residential has kind of been challenged throughout the course of the year. Anytime we introduce new products, that's not reflected in the price change i.e. it's just -- the delta shows up in organic growth or new products.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Got you. Did the change in price caused any pull forward into the quarter?

componenttext: No, not really. We think it's a pretty good comparison and it didn't really pull forward any activity.

componenttext: Just because I got disconnected here you can cut me off if you already went through it, but I think as a follow-up to Rich's question earlier on European margins, if we had to take that 10% and true [ph] it off just for the new business, from a mix perspective that you guys have acquired, maybe not pretending any margin improvements there, but kind of fully loaded, what would that look like now on a more apples-to-apples basis?

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll be giving full year 2016 guidance in the next quarterly conference call. The acquisitions are accretive to the overall margins. So you would expect to see, as you look at the European region next year to be north of 10%, certainly. As Dave high
componenttext: Yes, we'll be giving full year 2016 guidance in the next quarterly conference call. The acquisitions are accretive to the overall margins. So you would expect to see, as you look at the European region next year to be north of 10%, certainly. As Dave highlighted, the business has really made good progress relative to the margin expansion on the base business. We continue to get the carryover effects relative to the restructuring programs we executed last year. The team has done a great job on pricing. We talked about really looking at customer specific accounts and try to be more specific there in terms of implementing and executing price increases just moved in terms of facility, help bridge the gap from base business performance to get us closer to that 10% margin on base business. So a lot of good progress there. When we go out with guidance on a going-forward basis; we'll probably be talking about how the overall European region is performing and provide guidance relative to that aspect.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Okay, all right. So that explains that. How are you thinking about continued acquisition runway and size, tuck-in versus maybe letter transformational versus share buybacks at this point?

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We continue to be aggressive on working the acquisition pipeline. Deal size tends to be reflective of what you saw in AXA's, SimonsVoss or smaller. It's what our game is. We compare plenty of runway there. Patrick, some additional comments?
componenttext: We continue to be aggressive on working the acquisition pipeline. Deal size tends to be reflective of what you saw in AXA's, SimonsVoss or smaller. It's what our game is. We compare plenty of runway there. Patrick, some additional comments?

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So you guys are aware, we target a leverage ratio from three in a quarter to two and three quarters. We're a little bit north of that today, not concerning because of the free cash flow generation of this business. We delever fairly quickly and we'll do s
componenttext: So you guys are aware, we target a leverage ratio from three in a quarter to two and three quarters. We're a little bit north of that today, not concerning because of the free cash flow generation of this business. We delever fairly quickly and we'll do so next year. So I think next year as planned with kind of put us back in the middle of that range. And we've indicated previously that we've not have an issue. We go into say, 4 times leverage for the right transactions. And we also have our equity currency that we could use for the right type of strategic deal.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could sneak one more in on tax rate, if you didn't answer this. So AXA's onetime items, where are you? Is that exchange kind of expectations in terms of where you're trying to head?
componenttext: Okay. And if I could sneak one more in on tax rate, if you didn't answer this. So AXA's onetime items, where are you? Is that exchange kind of expectations in terms of where you're trying to head?

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: For this year, no. So the majority of the rate improvement for Q3 was onetime favorable discrete items. We got our full year effective rate of 20%, which puts Q4 around 22%, which was our beginning of the year guidance. We are still marching towards that
componenttext: For this year, no. So the majority of the rate improvement for Q3 was onetime favorable discrete items. We got our full year effective rate of 20%, which puts Q4 around 22%, which was our beginning of the year guidance. We are still marching towards that 20% target for 2016, making some good progress there. A little headwind relative to the acquisitions just given the nature of where the earnings are, but I think we'll be able to execute some tax planning strategy that mitigate that and get us within the target that we established last year for 20% in 2016.

componenttext: The 90 basis points of headwinds associated with the investments. I think earlier in the year you've been up closer to about 150 basis points. So it seems like maybe that's coming off, maybe now with Sense rollout that continues to [indiscernible]. I'm not sure. Maybe you can talk about that and just what do you expect that number to look like for the fourth quarter? But I guess more importantly, for 2016?

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we had -- beginning the year guidance had guided incremental investments around $0.15 to $0.20 per share impact year-to-date, we're down $0.15. Q4, you're going to see a tapering off. Maybe there's $0.02 to $0.03 impact. And the year-over-year imp
componenttext: Yes. So we had -- beginning the year guidance had guided incremental investments around $0.15 to $0.20 per share impact year-to-date, we're down $0.15. Q4, you're going to see a tapering off. Maybe there's $0.02 to $0.03 impact. And the year-over-year impact relative to the margin comes down maybe to around of 40 or 50 basis points. You may recall last year, Q4 in particular, really stepped up our activities associated with engineering, this repair retrofit market opportunity that Dave talked about making incremental investments in the channel, et cetera. So it does start coming down, you kind of look forward to 2016 and you would expect the incremental year-over-year investments to also decrease on a full year basis as we previously highlighted at our shareholder meeting in March.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And residential, I wonder if you could just talk about within kind of the conventional product offering. What competitive conditions within the Big Box look like right now to the extent was a this is impacting the residential margins.
componenttext: Okay. And residential, I wonder if you could just talk about within kind of the conventional product offering. What competitive conditions within the Big Box look like right now to the extent was a this is impacting the residential margins.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So from a competitive standpoint in Big Box, our results are strong. We think the overall demand, especially for renovation and retrofit, is positive. New home starts again will be choppy, but we think the normal is around 1.4 to 1.6. We like that. We thi
componenttext: So from a competitive standpoint in Big Box, our results are strong. We think the overall demand, especially for renovation and retrofit, is positive. New home starts again will be choppy, but we think the normal is around 1.4 to 1.6. We like that. We think the new products Schlage touched like Sense, like Pulls, actually stands the total available market for our products so are net positive, and I think we're executing well. I challenge all of you, understand the new Schlage Sense gives a superior product out there and I think will perform well in that environment versus the competition.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Last question, just within your portfolio North American businesses in the various lands in the markets you got there, do you watch 1 or 2 or 3 as particularly leading indicators? And what would you be seeing there right now?
componenttext: Okay. Last question, just within your portfolio North American businesses in the various lands in the markets you got there, do you watch 1 or 2 or 3 as particularly leading indicators? And what would you be seeing there right now?

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So ironically, our Door business, deal Kraft, is an early indicator because in the new construction you -- it's like segment and starts. It gives you an indication of what's ahead. And I'd say, generally, that business continues to lean positively. I thin
componenttext: So ironically, our Door business, deal Kraft, is an early indicator because in the new construction you -- it's like segment and starts. It gives you an indication of what's ahead. And I'd say, generally, that business continues to lean positively. I think all of these construction, whether it's residential, commercial, is capped by labor availability, land availability. And if I look at just frame, doorframes, that market continues to be positive.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: I guess, just the first question I wanted to ask, if you look at the midpoint of your prior guidance and the midpoint of this guidance, yes, there's moving pieces and I would just hoping if you could tell us me break it into a few buckets in terms of how much is the core guidance up, how much is acquisition, how much is the tax rate, and then maybe what the headwinds are from the Bocom and then maybe some of the Venezuela stuff. It sounds like there might be a little bit of incremental there from the divestiture.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you kind of take start with the beat [ph] relative to Q3 performance tax, $0.78, ops, $0.05 or so, [indiscernible] of a penny, the way you should probably think about Q4 is sort of the full year is that carries forward, and then you've got a negat
componenttext: Yes. If you kind of take start with the beat [ph] relative to Q3 performance tax, $0.78, ops, $0.05 or so, [indiscernible] of a penny, the way you should probably think about Q4 is sort of the full year is that carries forward, and then you've got a negative reduction on Bocom, which we mentioned the $0.05, and that's offset by acquisitions net of interest of a couple pennies and the general business or operations [indiscernible] is how I would kind of characterize it if you go midpoint to midpoint.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if we just completely ripped out Bocom, what would be the adjusted impact in the full year of '14? It'll be higher in the fourth quarter? I'm trying to understand because $0.05 is coming up for Bocom, but effectively, that would be divested
componenttext: Okay. And then if we just completely ripped out Bocom, what would be the adjusted impact in the full year of '14? It'll be higher in the fourth quarter? I'm trying to understand because $0.05 is coming up for Bocom, but effectively, that would be divested by the next time you guys report. I'm just trying to understand what the total impact on EPS could be from Bocom.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So year-over-year, $0.05. That assumes some profitability in the quarter, okay? We've got it in for the fourth quarter. If the divestiture takes place, let's say, December 1, for example, it would have some added pressure on earnings because a lot of
componenttext: Yes. So year-over-year, $0.05. That assumes some profitability in the quarter, okay? We've got it in for the fourth quarter. If the divestiture takes place, let's say, December 1, for example, it would have some added pressure on earnings because a lot of the revenue generation is in the month of December, just how the contracts work with the government, but we'll see and will talk about that when we get there.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the other question I had was just a broader question, but Dave, could you talk a little bit about just the safe schools initiatives. I don't know, you talked a little bit about it in the past, but just curious where we are maybe with those
componenttext: Okay. And then the other question I had was just a broader question, but Dave, could you talk a little bit about just the safe schools initiatives. I don't know, you talked a little bit about it in the past, but just curious where we are maybe with those initiatives and what's the opportunity for Allegion for the next few years for just safe schools?

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think safe schools is predominantly driven by funding. There is movement, the State of California had passed legislation that requires lock with visible signaling capability that you can visually see that secure for rooms with over 5 people. But there's
componenttext: I think safe schools is predominantly driven by funding. There is movement, the State of California had passed legislation that requires lock with visible signaling capability that you can visually see that secure for rooms with over 5 people. But there's still a long ways to go in this. We've created a consortium and awareness on this, but we're still in the front end of this initiative and I think we're providing some good thought leadership in terms of how do we keep students safe, but how do we also create an environment that allows them to exit, if required. I mean, you've got concerns of fire safety as well as violence safety. This is all opportunistic, but it continues to be in its infancy of development and I think it lacks funding.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Charlie Mitchell with Crédit Suisse.

componenttext: Sorry comments Julian Mitchell. Just a question around the European business, and I'm trying to understand the margin impact from acquisitions. In Q4, the last couple of years, you've had a very strong margin. What sort of margin rates should we expect for Europe right now this quarter exiting the year?

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So normally, we don't provide quarterly guidance relative to per regions, but given the accretion relative to the acquired businesses and some of the improvements that the business has executed on during the course of the year, north of last year, you're
componenttext: So normally, we don't provide quarterly guidance relative to per regions, but given the accretion relative to the acquired businesses and some of the improvements that the business has executed on during the course of the year, north of last year, you're exactly right. Seasonally, it is the best quarter for that segment of our business. I think it was around 11% or so last year. So you can expect the results for this quarter to be north of that in aggregate.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then just my follow-up is on the Asia business. Maybe give us a sense of the scale of that business, and the profitability expo kind of what the strategy there is from here. Is this sort of consolidating what you have left? Do you look to kind of regr
componenttext: And then just my follow-up is on the Asia business. Maybe give us a sense of the scale of that business, and the profitability expo kind of what the strategy there is from here. Is this sort of consolidating what you have left? Do you look to kind of regrow with acquisitions of that lowered base?

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So think about Asia Pacific in our mechanical core business, the $90 million to $100 million slightly profitable on today's scale. We'll work to put into profitability and growth into that region similar to what we've done in Europe. I think the thing to
componenttext: So think about Asia Pacific in our mechanical core business, the $90 million to $100 million slightly profitable on today's scale. We'll work to put into profitability and growth into that region similar to what we've done in Europe. I think the thing to remember, Asia Pacific, from a mechanical and electronic standpoint, grew low double digits in the quarter. So with our FHS acquisition, the Milre acquisition, we think we're building a base there that can compete, and it's another strategic issue that will go to drive what's our long-term view there. But we think we're positive on the region. We think China, India, the whole area will continue to be a growth opportunity for us and will position ourselves over the long term.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Sprague from Vertical Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Sprague from Vertical Research.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was also off for a few minutes. I apologize if any of this is repetitive, but I just want to get a little bit more into price cost. Patrick, can you give us some idea of how much of the realized price you saw was just kind of actions to counter FX versu
componenttext: I was also off for a few minutes. I apologize if any of this is repetitive, but I just want to get a little bit more into price cost. Patrick, can you give us some idea of how much of the realized price you saw was just kind of actions to counter FX versus kind of real like-for-like price? That's the first question.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the actions implemented to offset FX predominantly was in Europe, smaller part of our business, but they did see some good price pull through in the quarter. But from an overall perspective, relative to the total company, small impact on price. So
componenttext: Yes. So the actions implemented to offset FX predominantly was in Europe, smaller part of our business, but they did see some good price pull through in the quarter. But from an overall perspective, relative to the total company, small impact on price. So the majority of the price improvement you saw coming through in Americas, very little FX related. And so we would expect with a new price increase announced this quarter, hopefully, that trend will continue going forward.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, I missed, what did you say the size of that price increase?
componenttext: I'm sorry, I missed, what did you say the size of that price increase?

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Excuse me?
componenttext: Excuse me?

componenttext: Did you say the size of that price increase earlier on the call? I missed that.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we didn't. I mean, the list price is always announced at a higher level, and then when you settle after discounts and rebates, et cetera, it's lower. But normally, we look to try to get out a 1% price, net price improvement year-over-year, that's mark
componenttext: No, we didn't. I mean, the list price is always announced at a higher level, and then when you settle after discounts and rebates, et cetera, it's lower. But normally, we look to try to get out a 1% price, net price improvement year-over-year, that's market sometimes difficult to get, particularly in the residential segment.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. And then you mentioned inflation in your opening remarks. I'm sure there's some meaningful cost deflation in parts of the equation, but net-net, the cost structure is experiencing inflation. Can you provide a little bit more color on that?
componenttext: Right. And then you mentioned inflation in your opening remarks. I'm sure there's some meaningful cost deflation in parts of the equation, but net-net, the cost structure is experiencing inflation. Can you provide a little bit more color on that?

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the inflation comment really, salaries, people oriented type costs. Materials, year-to-date, I'd say we're at a net positive. When I look at how price has reacted, particularly given the commodity cost today, I mean, you're looking at spot rates f
componenttext: Yes. So the inflation comment really, salaries, people oriented type costs. Materials, year-to-date, I'd say we're at a net positive. When I look at how price has reacted, particularly given the commodity cost today, I mean, you're looking at spot rates for brass, zinc, copper, et cetera, 28 plus percent below last year's average rate, and we would expect to participate in that decline in cost. Keep in mind, our material, raw material purchases, not a large percentage overall material buy, but we do enter into supplier contracts as we talked about previously. So no immediate impact on our operating results, and certainly, as we look forward to 2016 given where commodity rates are trading today, it should be a positive effect on our margins going forward.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just one quick one finally, and then I'll jump off. Just the deals you said are similar in Q2 than Q3. Why would that be if you only had kind of a partial quarter impact in Q3? Is there some other purchase accounting or some other dynamic going throug
componenttext: And just one quick one finally, and then I'll jump off. Just the deals you said are similar in Q2 than Q3. Why would that be if you only had kind of a partial quarter impact in Q3? Is there some other purchase accounting or some other dynamic going through or seasonality in the business that you bought?

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it's predominantly the interest impact. So operationally, much higher uplift on the results, but it's the full quarter effect on the interest, and we're adding in all the interest costs associated with the 300 million senior notes issued at the en
componenttext: Yes. So it's predominantly the interest impact. So operationally, much higher uplift on the results, but it's the full quarter effect on the interest, and we're adding in all the interest costs associated with the 300 million senior notes issued at the end of September. So you've got the full quarter effect of that offsetting the operational impact.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Allegion Q3 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded.I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Tom Martineau, Director of
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Allegion Q3 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded.
I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Tom Martineau, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, please begin.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Liz. Good morning, everyone. Welcome, and thank you for joining us for the Third Quarter 2015 Allegion Earnings Call. With me today is Dave Petratis, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Patrick Shannon, Senior Vice President an
componenttext:
Thank you, Liz. Good morning, everyone. Welcome, and thank you for joining us for the Third Quarter 2015 Allegion Earnings Call. With me today is Dave Petratis, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Patrick Shannon, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Allegion. 
Our earnings release, which was issued earlier this morning, and a presentation, which we will refer to in today's call, are available on our website at www.allegion.com. This call will be recorded and archived on our website. 
Please go to Slide #2. Statements made in today's call that are not historical facts are considered forward-looking statements and are made pursuant to the Safe Harbor Provisions of federal securities law. Please see our SEC filings for description of some of the factors that may cause actual results to vary from anticipated results. The company assumes no obligation to update these forward-looking statements. 
Our release and today's commentary include non-GAAP financial measures, which exclude the impact of restructuring, acquisition and divestiture, expenses and charges in current year results and restructuring and spin expenses from prior year results. We believe these adjustments reflect the underlying performance of the business when discussing operational results in comparing to the prior year periods. Please refer to the reconciliation in the financial tables of our press release for further details. 
Dave and Patrick will discuss our third quarter 2015 results, which will be followed by a Q&A session. [Operator Instructions] 
Please go to Slide 3, and I'll turn the call over to Dave.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'm pleased to report another strong quarter for Allegion with nice organic growth and operating margin expansion. There has been a tremendous amount of positive activity during this past quar
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'm pleased to report another strong quarter for Allegion with nice organic growth and operating margin expansion. There has been a tremendous amount of positive activity during this past quarter, and we'll be covering in today's call. 
Revenues of $544 million grew 5.1% on an organic basis. Total revenue declined 0.4%, reflecting the negative impact of foreign currency. Of note, organic growth for the business has averaged more than 6% over the last 12 months. And our electronics portfolio continues to perform well in the quarter, improving more than 30% versus prior year. We have seen a continuous acceleration of the electronics growth rate, reflected of a ongoing electromechanical transformation and supportive of our increased investment in accelerating new electronic security products and solutions. 
The Americas segment grew 7% organically, driven by continued strength in both the nonresidential and residential business. In EMEIA, organic growth of 2% reflects a slight improvement in the region, although market recovery continues to be mixed across countries. Our one decline this quarter is in the Asia Pacific region with negative organic growth of 10%. Patrick will provide more details on this later, but the decline is primarily driven by weaknesses in our system integration business in China. 
Adjusted operating income of $116.8 million increased 5.3% versus the prior year. We realized operating margin expansion in all regions and improved overall margin by 120 basis points. We continue to show margin improvement while absorbing incremental investments, investments predominantly in new product and channel initiatives creating the 90 basis point headwind in the quarter. Adjusted earnings per share of $0.92 increased 35% versus the prior year, driven primarily from improved operating performance, acquisition and a lower effective tax rate, partially offset by incremental investments and foreign exchange impact. This is our fifth straight quarter with double-digit earnings per share growth. We are raising our full year 2015 adjusted earnings per share guidance of a -- to a range of $2.85 to $2.90 per share. 
Please go to Slide 4. We have been extremely active as a company affecting change in line with our long-term growth strategies. I'm happy to report that we successfully closed the 3 acquisitions mentioned last quarter within the expected time frame. We are well underway with the integration work, and have already seen contribution in our third quarter results. We are excited to realize the benefits of a broader electronics portfolio as well as seeing the expansion of our position as a global leader in portable security. 
During the quarter, we completed the divestiture of our Venezuela business. This decision was made to reduce risk associated with an uncertain economic operating environment. Also in the quarter, we announced our intent to sell a majority stake in our Bocom Wincent business in China. Although a market leader in the system integration industry in China, this business was not deemed to be a good strategic fit with the rest of the Allegion portfolio. The sale has the benefit of reducing risk in an environment that is currently realizing a economic flowing combined with tightening credit, and reduces the high cap -- capital requirements of the business. This decision allows us to prioritize efforts and resources on core mechanical and electronic hardware solutions. And earlier this month, we reached an agreement with regard to the restructuring plan for our CISA business in Italy that will ensure a long-term viability enhance the customer experience. CISA remains a critical part of the European portfolio, and will continue to provide innovative solutions for convergence of mechanical and electronic technologies. In conjunction with the plan, we will begin to transition products of nonspecialized product to Flex, an existing supplier of Allegion today. Flex offers innovative design, engineering, manufacturing, real-time supply chain insight and logistical services to companies of all sizes in various industries around today's connected world. By partnering with Flex, we will simplify and optimize our supply chain, reducing risks associated with the transition, and will better serve our customer needs. And last, we enhanced our debt structure with the issuance of $300 million of senior notes as well as completing an amendment and extension of our senior credit facility. The proceeds of the senior notes were used to repay a portion of our outstanding borrowings under the revolving credit facility as a result of the previous completed acquisitions. 
Please go to Slide 5. On September 1, we launched pre-orders for Schlage's newest Internet of Things innovation, the Schlage Sense Smart Deadbolt at amazon.com, homedepot.com and build.com. Schlage Sense is one of the strongest, most intelligent Bluetooth enabled locks on the market with the highest industry ratings for security and durability. It's designed to work with Apple HomeKit, allowing users to control their door lock as part of their smart home. Apple HomeKit technology provides advanced security with end-to-end encryption and authentication between the Schlage Sense Smart Deadbolt and an iPhone, an iPad or an iPod Touch. With an Apple TV in home, users can enjoy the convenience of remote access. Additionally, HomeKit let's consumers talk to the -- to talk to unlock their Schlage Sense using Siri voice control. In November, Schlage Sense will be available in Apple Stores and online. This lock has received media attention from large industry intruders like CNET, and Hardware and Building Supply dealer, along with craze from tech industry publications like Mashable, TechCrunch and MacRumors. I'm also proud to say it's been featured by large national media outlets like Fortune and CNBC. Schlage Sense will be officially be available in retail in November in selected Big Box stores like Home Depot and Lowe's. 
Patrick will now walk you through the financial results, and I'll be back to update you on our full year 2015 guidance.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining the call this morning. Please go to Slide #6. This slide depicts the components of our revenue growth in the third quarter as well as our growth by regional segments. As indicated, we deliv
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining the call this morning. 
Please go to Slide #6. This slide depicts the components of our revenue growth in the third quarter as well as our growth by regional segments. As indicated, we delivered 5.1% organic growth in the third quarter, supported by incremental volume that reflects improving market fundamentals, price improvements and early traction on our key organic growth investments and products and channels. We realized solid organic growth in Americas and EMEIA segments. As expected, unfavorable foreign currency rates continue to be a headwind to revenue growth noted by the negative 7.5% decline. All reporting segments were impacted by currency due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar against currencies in EMEIA and Asia Pacific as well as the devaluation of the Venezuelan Bolivar. Acquisitions and divestitures provided 2% of growth, which includes contributions from acquisitions offset by Venezuelan divestiture. 
Please go to Slide #7. Reported net revenues for the quarter were $544.5 million. This reflects a decrease of 0.4% versus the prior year, up 5.1% on an organic basis. We realized strong organic growth in Americas and EMEIA across most product segments. We continue to experience great progress in electronic product growth, up over 30% compared to the prior-year period. This growth was across both residential and commercial segments, and is the result of new products and accelerated adoption of electronic products. 
Adjusted operating income of $116.8 million grew 5.3% compared to the prior year. Incremental volume leverage and acquisitions compensated for increased investment spending and unfavorable foreign currency exchange rate movements. Adjusted operating margin of 21.5% reflects an increase of 120 basis points versus the prior year. Incremental investments made in the areas of new product development, channel and market expansion and certain infrastructure programs had a negative impact of 90 basis points on the quarter. The adjusted EBITDA margin of 23.7% is a record performance since the company went public in December 2013. 
Please go to Slide #8. This slide reflects our EPS reconciliation for the third quarter. For the third quarter 2014, reported EPS was $0.65, adjusting for prior year onetime separation and restructuring expenses of $0.03, the 2014 adjusted EPS was $0.68. Operational results increased EPS by $0.12 as pricing, productivity and favorable operating leverage were more than offset inflation and unfavorable currency exchange impacts. The decrease in the adjusted effective tax rate drove $0.15 per share improvement versus the prior year. The improvement reflects favorable changes in the mix of income earned and lower rate jurisdictions, and the benefit of discrete tax items recorded in the quarter. Acquisitions and interest expense added $0.02, as did other net items. Next, incremental investments related to ongoing growth opportunities for new product development and channel management as well as corporate initiatives tied to our strategy specific to taxes and IT investments were a $0.03 reduction. And lastly, the net year-over-year impact of Venezuela at current exchange rates is a $0.04 reduction. This results in adjusted third quarter 2015 EPS of $0.92 per share. 
Continuing on, we have a negative $1.20 per share reduction for charges related to the Bocom Wincent and Venezuelan business divestitures as well as acquisition and restructuring expenses. After giving effect to these onetime items, we arrived at the third quarter 2015 reported EPS of negative $0.28. 
Please go to Slide #9. Third quarter revenues for the Americas region were $418.9 million, down 1% or an increase of 7% on an organic basis. Higher volumes, pricing and contribution from the acquisition of Zero compensated for unfavorable currency movements in Canada, in Venezuela and the divestiture of the Venezuelan business. The higher volumes reflect strong organic growth in both residential and nonresidential products. This reflects better-than-market performance driven by our new product and channel initiatives. Americas adjusted operating income of $122.2 million was down 1% versus the prior-year period. Pricing and productivity more than offset inflation and investment, while incremental volume was absorbed by unfavorable foreign exchange rates in the Venezuelan divestiture. Adjusted operating margin for the quarter increased 10 basis points, while absorbing incremental investment spending that created a 70 basis point headwind in the quarter and unfavorable mix due to the Venezuelan divestiture. 
Please go to Slide #10. Third quarter revenues for the EMEIA region were $91.5 million, up 2.2% both on a reported and in an organic basis. The growth was driven by strong pricing within the mechanical business and modest volume increases. Significant ongoing currency headwinds were offset by recent acquisitions completed in the quarter. EMEIA adjusted operating income of $5.9 million was up $4.7 million or 392% versus the prior-year period. Adjusted operating margin for the quarter increased 510 basis points, reflecting continued improvements in an ongoing business transformation as well as partial quarter contributions from the recent acquisitions which were accretive to the region's margins. 
Please go to Slide #11. Third quarter revenues for the Asia Pacific region were $34.1 million, flat to the prior year. Revenues were down 10.2% on an organic basis. Strength in the hardware business and acquisitions offset unfavorable foreign exchange and a decline in the Bocom Wincent system integration business. The decline reflects the slowdown of the China business environment and the delay of a few large projects. Note that this business historically relies on large project awards in the second half of the year. During the third quarter, projects in the pipeline have been delayed, resulting in a year-over-year reduction in revenue of approximately $6 million or negative 36%. We also expect an impact to the fourth quarter organic growth rates, which Dave will discuss later. Of note, the announced divestiture of Bocom Wincent reduces future risk inherent in the seasonal nature of the business both in terms of size and timing of awards. Asia Pacific adjusted operating income of $0.7 million was up $1.2 million or 240% versus the prior year. Adjusted operating margin improved 360 basis points due to the mixed shift of hardware volume, productivity and acquisitions which offset inflation and currency exchange impacts. 
Please go to Slide #12. Year-to-date available cash flow for 2015 was $98.7 million, a reduction of $36.3 million compared to the prior-year period. The reduction in year-over-year cash flow was due to increased operating cash requirements and onetime cash tax payments, partially offset by reduced capital expenditures. We continue to operate with an effective working capital structure and continue to see improvement in working capital as a percentage of revenue as well as our cash conversion cycle. We expect full year available cash flow for the business to be approximately $200 million. This guidance incorporates a reduction in anticipated 2015 collections for our Bocom Wincent business and slightly higher working capital requirements. 
I will now hand it back over to Dave for an update on our full year 2015 guidance.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Patrick. Please go to Slide 13. Looking at full year revenue guidance, we are increasing our growth expectations for the full year by 1 point. In the Americas, we're improving organic revenue growth by 50 basis points reflecting the third quart
componenttext:
Thank you, Patrick. Please go to Slide 13. Looking at full year revenue guidance, we are increasing our growth expectations for the full year by 1 point. In the Americas, we're improving organic revenue growth by 50 basis points reflecting the third quarter results. Reported full year revenue growth for the Americas remains consistent to prior guidance as the increases in organic revenue is offset by increased currency headwinds. We see the end markets as unchanged from prior guidance with regard to verticals or construction growth. 
Total revenue for EMEIA region now reflects the inclusion of the SimonsVoss and AXA acquisitions, while organic growth guidance remains unchanged. The largest change occurs within our Asia Pacific region where we now forecast organic revenues to decline for the full year by negative 13% to 15%. This impact flows through the total Asia Pacific revenues that are primarily offset by the inclusion of the Milre acquisition. 
As Patrick mentioned earlier, when discussing Q3 results, the revenue call down is related to the Bocom Wincent system integration business where we now forecast a number of large projects to be delayed until 2016. And note that we would continue to include Bocom Wincent in our guidance as announced, but not yet closed transaction. Furthermore, margins for Bocom Wincent are historically strongest in the fourth quarter due to increased volume, which compensates for operating losses in the first 3 quarters. Given the reduction in volume, we expect full year margins for Asia Pacific to be down from prior year and close to breakeven. We estimate the earnings impact of the lower Bocom Wincent revenues in the fourth quarter to be a headwind of approximately $0.05 versus prior guidance. Inclusive of this impact, we are still able to increase full year adjusted EPS from continuing operations to a range of $2.85 to $2.90. This reflects an improvement of our adjusted effective tax rate now estimated to be 20% for the full year and improved operational performance. Furthermore, this incorporates the impact of acquisitions as well as increased interest expense related to the new senior notes. 
Please go to Slide 14. The third quarter results were very strong and represented solid growth with a 5.1% organic revenue increase, a 120 basis point margin expansion and adjusted earnings per share growth of over 35%. From a market perspective, the trends for the U.S. market are still leaning positive, although economic data, it remains choppy. And after a long recessionary cycle, we are seeing signs of slight improvements in our primary European geographies. In Asia Pacific, China growth is decelerating, while other countries outside China are holding. Overall, the business continues to perform well, and we are executing at a high level. We're making the top portfolio decisions that need to be made, and we'll continue to execute on our strategies to drive profitable growth and customer satisfaction. 
Now Patrick and I will be happy to take your questions.

This program is got to be done correctly and it takes people. And -- so pleased with the results and we'll continue to work on these areas.

componenttextpreview: So you guys are aware -- I mean, we target a leverage ratio from 3.25 to 2.75. We're a little bit north of that today, not concerning because of the free cash flow generation of this business. We delever fairly quickly, and we'll do so next year. So I thi
componenttext: So you guys are aware -- I mean, we target a leverage ratio from 3.25 to 2.75. We're a little bit north of that today, not concerning because of the free cash flow generation of this business. We delever fairly quickly, and we'll do so next year. So I think next year's plan would kind of put us back in the middle of that range. And we've indicated previously that would not have an issue, would go into say 4 times leverage for the right transactions. And we also have our equity currency that we could use for the right type of strategic deal.

componenttextpreview: For this year, no. So the majority of the rate improvement for Q3 was onetime favorable discrete items. We got a full year effective rate of 20%, which puts Q4 around 22%, which was our beginning-of-the-year guidance. We are still marching towards the 20%
componenttext: For this year, no. So the majority of the rate improvement for Q3 was onetime favorable discrete items. We got a full year effective rate of 20%, which puts Q4 around 22%, which was our beginning-of-the-year guidance. We are still marching towards the 20% target for 2016, making some good progress there. A little headwind relative to the acquisitions just given the nature of where the earnings are, but I think we'll be able to execute some tax planning strategies that mitigate that and get us within the target that we established last year for 20% in 2016.

componenttext: Yes. So we had -- beginning the year guidance had guided incremental investments around $0.15 to $0.20 per share impact year-to-date, we're around $0.15. Q4, you're going to see a tapering off. Maybe there's $0.02 to $0.03 impact. And the year-over-year impact relative to the margin comes down, maybe, to around 40 or 50 basis points. You may recall, last year, Q4 in particular, really stepped up our activities associated with engineering, this repair retrofit market opportunity that Dave talked about making incremental investments in the channel, et cetera. So it does start coming down, you kind of look forward to 2016 and you would expect the incremental year-over-year investments to also decrease on a full year basis, as we previously highlighted at our shareholder meeting in March.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So from a competitive standpoint in Big Box, our results are strong. We think the overall demand, especially for renovation and retrofit, is positive. New home starts again will be choppy, but we think they normalize around 1.4 to 1.6. We like that. We th
componenttext: So from a competitive standpoint in Big Box, our results are strong. We think the overall demand, especially for renovation and retrofit, is positive. New home starts again will be choppy, but we think they normalize around 1.4 to 1.6. We like that. We think the new products Schlage Touch, Schlage Sense, Schlage Pulls, actually expands the total available market for our products, so are net positives, and I think we're executing well. I challenge all of you, understand the new Schlage Sense gives a superior product out there and I think will perform well in that environment versus the competition.

componenttext: So ironically, our Door business, deal Kraft, is an early indicator because in the new construction, it's the [indiscernible] and starts. It gives you an indication of what's ahead. And I'd say, generally, that business continues to lean positively. I think all of this construction, whether it's residential, commercial, is capped by labor availability, land availability. And if I look at just frame -- doorframes, that market continues to be positive.

If the divestiture takes place, let's say, December 1, for example, it would have some added pressure on earnings because a lot of the revenue generation is in the month of December, just the way the contracts work with the government, but we'll see and will talk about that when we get there.

componenttext: Okay. Okay. And then the other question I had was just -- it's a broader question, but, Dave, could you talk a little bit about just the safe schools initiatives. I don't know. You've talked about it a little bit in the past, but just curious where we are, maybe, with those initiatives, and what's the opportunity for Allegion over the next few years from just safe schools?

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think safe schools is predominantly driven by funding. There is movement. The State of California has passed legislation that requires lock with visible signaling capability that you can visually see that is secure for rooms with over 5 people. But ther
componenttext: I think safe schools is predominantly driven by funding. There is movement. The State of California has passed legislation that requires lock with visible signaling capability that you can visually see that is secure for rooms with over 5 people. But there's still a long way to go on this. We've created a [indiscernible] consortium and awareness on this, but we're still in the front end of this initiative. And I think we're providing some good thought leadership in terms of how do we keep students safe, but how do we also create an environment that allows them to exit, if required? I mean, you've got concerns of fire safety as well as violence safety. This is all opportunistic, but it continues to be in its infancy in development and I think lacks funding.

componenttext: So think about Asia Pacific in our mechanical core business, the $90 million to $100 million, slightly profitable on today's scale. So with our FHS acquisition, the Milre acquisition, we think we're building a base there that can compete, and it's another strategic issue that will go to drive what's our long-term view there. But we think we're positive on the region. We think China, India, the whole area will continue to be a growth opportunity for us and will position ourselves over the long term.

headline: Allegion Plc, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the inflation comment really, salaries, people-oriented type costs, materials, year-to-date, I'd say we're at a net positive. When I look at how price has reacted, particularly given the commodity cost today. I mean, you're looking at spot rates f
componenttext: Yes, so the inflation comment really, salaries, people-oriented type costs, materials, year-to-date, I'd say we're at a net positive. When I look at how price has reacted, particularly given the commodity cost today. I mean, you're looking at spot rates for brass, zinc, copper, et cetera, 20-plus percent below last year's average rate, and we would expect to participate in that decline in cost. Keep in mind, our material -- raw material purchases, not a large percentage of our overall material buy, but we do enter into supplier contracts as we've talked about previously. So no immediate impact on our operating results, but certainly, as we look forward to 2016, given where commodity rates are trading today, it should be a positive effect on our margins going forward.
